newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries range-bound after Beige Book.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries range-bound after Beige Book.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries remained mired in narrow ranges after the Federal Reserve released its Beige Book at midday on Wednesday.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was off 3/32 to 101-22/32, its 6.37 percent yield unchanged from the opening.
"People appear content with their views, content to stay long," said Chris Rupkey, vice president and economist at Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi.
The Beige Book, an account of business conditions around the nation, said the economy grew moderately in November.
While the Beige Book characterized the labor market as tight, it saw no sign of accelerating wage pressures.
The bond market did not react to that friendly news.

Rupkey noted that despite Wednesday's narrow-ranged trade, the bond market had sold off about a point from Tuesday's intra-day high achieved after the government said October new single-family home sales fell sharply in October.
"The market's tone is slightly negative," said Rupkey. "If we can cut some of that selloff (from Tuesday intraday highs), it would put the market in a better technical position."
To move higher, the market has to see the March futures contract get above 116-00, Rupkey said. In early afternoon trade, the March contract was down 8/32 to 115-24/32.
Rupkey also said the report of the Boskin panel on the Consumer Price Index had mostly been discounted.

As expected, the Boskin panel said U.S. inflation had been overstated by 1.1 percentage points per year. It said the bias in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) would add $148 billion to the federal budget deficit in 2006 if it were not fixed.
The Boskin Panel recommended that the Labor Department publish two prices indexes, one monthly and one annually.
The Boskin panel said Congress and President Clinton should consider changes in indexing taxes and benefits.
The government's report that U.S. housing completions slipped 0.7 percent to an annualized rate of 1.360 units had no market impact.
"It's kind of a neutral day," said Rupkey. "If we can't get up above 116-00, we might see some people liquidate a few more bonds before three p.m. (1500 EST/2000 GMT)," he said.
The Federal Reserve added temporary reserves to the banking system through overnight system repurchases.
Three-month bill rates were up one basis point to 4.90 percent. Six-month and year-bill rates were unchanged at 4.99 percent and 5.10 percent, respectively.

The two-year note was unchanged at 100-1/32, yielding 5.61 percent. Five-year notes were down 1/32 to 100-3/32, yielding 5.85 percent. Ten-year notes were down 3/32 to 103-4/32, yielding 6.07 percent.
